sections.heading: The Core Difference: SOV vs SVO
sections.content:
Japanese uses SOV (Subject-Object-Verb) order. The verb always comes last.

English (SVO): I eat sushi Japanese (SOV): 私は 寿司を 食べます (I sushi eat)

This fundamental difference affects how you build every sentence.

sections.heading: Basic SOV Pattern
sections.content: [Subject] は [Object] を [Verb] Topic marker Object marker

children.heading: Examples
children.content: 私は本を読む watashi wa hon wo yomu I (topic) book (object) read "I read books" 田中さんは日本語を勉強する Tanaka-san wa nihongo wo benkyou suru "Tanaka studies Japanese" 猫は魚を食べる neko wa sakana wo taberu "The cat eats fish"

sections.heading: Why Verb Position Matters
sections.content: The verb at the end creates different communication patterns:

children.heading: 1. Suspense Until the End
children.content:
You don't know the action until the sentence completes:

私は昨日新しいレストランで友達と美味しいイタリア料理を... "Yesterday at a new restaurant with friends delicious Italian food I..." 食べました ✓ "ate" 食べませんでした ✗ "didn't eat"

The final verb changes everything.

children.heading: 2. Easy to Add Details
children.content:
Insert modifiers anywhere before the verb:

本を読む → 面白い本を読む → 図書館で面白い本を読む book read → interesting book read → library at interesting book read

children.heading: 3. Negation Comes Last
children.content:
食べる (eat) → 食べない (don't eat) 行く (go) → 行かない (don't go)

The positive/negative decision is at the end.

children.heading: Adding Location (で)
children.content: [Subject] は [Location] で [Object] を [Verb] 私は図書館で本を読む "I read books at the library" 学生は教室で勉強する "Students study in the classroom"

children.heading: Adding Time
children.content:
Time words typically come early:

[Time] [Subject] は [Object] を [Verb] 今日私は映画を見る "Today I watch a movie" 昨日田中さんは寿司を食べた "Yesterday Tanaka ate sushi"

children.heading: Adding Destination (に/へ)
children.content: [Subject] は [Destination] に/へ [Verb of movement] 私は学校に行く "I go to school" 友達は日本へ来る "My friend comes to Japan"

sections.heading: Multiple Objects
sections.content:
Japanese can have multiple を objects with compound verbs:

私はペンを持って本を読む "I hold a pen and read a book" (Literally: pen holding, book read)

sections.heading: The Flexible Subject
sections.content:
Unlike English, Japanese often omits the subject when obvious from context:

何を食べますか？ "What will you eat?" 寿司を食べます (Not: 私は寿司を食べます) "(I) eat sushi"

The subject is understood from context.

sections.heading: Particles Define Roles
sections.content:
Word order is flexible because particles mark grammatical roles :

私は寿司を食べる ✓ 寿司を私は食べる ✓ (emphasis on sushi)

Both are correct. Particles (は, を) show which is subject/object.

Impossible in English: "Sushi I eat" ✗ (word order broken) "I sushi eat" ✗ (word order broken)

children.heading: 1. Simple Statement
children.content: [Noun] は [Noun] です これは本です "This is a book"

children.heading: 2. Action Sentence
children.content: [Subject] は [Object] を [Verb] 私は水を飲む "I drink water"

children.heading: 3. Existence
children.content: [Location] に [Thing] が ある/いる 机の上に本がある "There is a book on the desk"

children.heading: 4. Movement
children.content: [Subject] は [Place] に/へ 行く/来る 学校に行く "Go to school"

sections.heading: Compound Sentences
sections.content:
Connect with て-form or conjunctions:

私は朝ごはんを食べて、学校に行く "I eat breakfast and go to school" 雨が降ったから、家にいた "Because it rained, I stayed home"

The main verb still comes last in each clause.

sections.heading: Questions
sections.content:
Question sentences maintain SOV order, just add か:

あなたは寿司を食べますか？ "Do you eat sushi?" どこに行きますか？ "Where are you going?"

sections.heading: Comparison Chart
sections.content: | Language | Structure | Example | | -------- | --------- | ---------------------- | | English | SVO | I eat sushi | | Japanese | SOV | 私は寿司を食べる | | English | SVO | She studies Japanese | | Japanese | SOV | 彼女は日本語を勉強する |

children.heading: Mistake 1: Verb Not Last
children.content: Wrong: 私は食べる寿司を ❌ Right: 私は寿司を食べる ✓

children.heading: Mistake 2: Missing Particles
children.content:
Wrong: 私 本 読む ❌ Right: 私は本を読む ✓

Particles are essential even if word order is flexible.

children.heading: Mistake 3: Copying English Order
children.content:
Wrong: 私は行く図書館に ❌ Right: 私は図書館に行く ✓

Don't translate word-by-word from English.

sections.heading: Practice Building Sentences
sections.content:
Start with the verb, then add pieces:

Choose verb: 食べる (eat) Add object: 寿司を食べる (eat sushi) Add subject: 私は寿司を食べる (I eat sushi) Add details: 私は昨日寿司を食べた (I ate sushi yesterday)

sections.heading: Key Takeaways
sections.content:
✓ Verb always comes last ✓ Subject often omitted when clear ✓ Particles mark roles, not position ✓ Flexible word order for emphasis ✓ Main action/state revealed at sentence end

Master this pattern and you've mastered Japanese sentence structure. Everything else builds on SOV.

Next: Word Order Rules

Related:

Basic Sentence Patterns Particles Overview Verb Basics

examples.sentence: Add object: 寿司を食べる (eat sushi)
Add subject: 私は寿司を食べる (I eat sushi)
Add details: 私は昨日寿司を食べた (I ate sushi yesterday)
